title: Trump, seeking damage control, weighs less aggressive approach in Minneapolis | The World | ABC NEWS
description: The fallout is continuing after a second fatal shooting in the US by immigration agents as the Trump administration faces criticism from both sides of the political divide. The controversial border patrol commander Greg Bovino has been pulled from the frontlines, and there are now calls by Democrats and some Republican senators for Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem to step down. Jared Mondschein from The United States Studies Centre tells The World Donald Trump's latest moves can be considered a back-down. #ABCTheWorld #ABCAsiaPacific  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Trump threatens major attack on Iran as large US naval fleet deployed | ABC NEWS
description: US President Donald Trump has threatened Iran with a ‘far worse’ attack than the US strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities in 2025. Washington is warning Tehran that time is running out to reach a deal on its nuclear program. The US president says a large armada led by aircraft carrier USS Abraham Lincoln is en route to Iran and ready to use ‘speed and violence’ in necessary.  Donald Trump had previously promised to support anti-regime protesters in Iran during the Iranian Revolutionary Guard’s brutal crackdown on dissidents. title: What's on the agenda for Keir Starmer's meeting with Xi Jinping? | ABC NEWS
description: Sir Keir Starmer has touched down in Beijing to begin the first visit by a UK prime minister in eight years.  He is set to meet with Chinese leader Xi Jinping, as Downing Street seeks to reset relations with China after a frosty period.  While economic cooperation and visa-free travel are on his agenda, the British leader is under increasing pressure to address human rights issues such as the detention of British activist Jimmy Lai. title: Perth Invasion Day rally incident investigated as potential terror act | ABC NEWS
description: Authorities are investigating an alleged bomb attack on a crowd of Invasion Day protesters in Perth as a possible terror incident.  A joint counter-terrorism team comprised of the ASIO, the AFP and WA police allege a 31-year-old threw a homemade explosive device designed to detonate and could have seriously harmed people.  The suspect has been charged with intent to endanger life, health and safety and making or possessing explosive under suspicious circumstances. title: Why Pauline Hanson is so popular with Gen X men | ABC News Daily podcast
description: One Nation’s support is surging.   That’s according to successive opinion polls this year which have Pauline Hanson’s party with a primary vote higher than it’s ever been.    Today, Tony Barry, director at the Redbridge Group and former Liberal Party strategist on the voters expressing support for One Nation, whether it will translate into actual votes and why the major parties need to take notice.    Featured:    Tony Barry, director at RedBridge Group

title: Telstra warns older iPhones may be unable to connect to Triple Zero | ABC NEWS
description: Telstra says it is investigating a technical issue that is preventing some older Apple devices from connecting to its mobile network, including Triple Zero (000). Customers are advised to delay software updates on affected devices and find alternative ways to communicate if needed. title: ICE agents who shot Alex Pretti put on leave | ABC NEWS
description: Two US immigration agents involved in the fatal shooting of Alex Pretti in Minneapolis have been put on administrative leave. Border Patrol official Greg Bovino has been removed as the head of the Trump administration’s immigration crackdown in Minnesota after US citizens Alex Pretti and 37-year-old woman Renee Good were shot by federal officers in two separate incidents. Border czar Tom Homan has been dispatched to replace Bovino, as President Donald Trump attempts to rein in the operation in fear of upsetting his MAGA base. title: Last Israeli hostage taken by Hamas during October 7 attack laid to rest | ABC NEWS
description: The final Israeli hostage taken by Hamas during the October 7 attack has been laid to rest after 843 days. Hundreds of people lined the streets waving Israeli flags as Ran Gvili's body was driven in a procession from a military base near Tel Aviv to his hometown of Meitar, where he was buried. title: NT Chief Minister yet to address backlash over controversial pick for NT Administrator | ABC News
description: There's still no sign of Northern Territory Chief Minister Lia Finocchiaro, who's yet to address backlash to her controversial pick of former cattle industry leader David Connolly as administrator. Lia Finocchiaro failed to front the cameras again, almost two weeks after Mr Connolly's controversial past social media posts were first reported. By Jack Hislop for ABC News Northern Territory. title: China-Australia taskforce to investigate coffee attack on Brisbane baby | ABC NEWS
description: China's Ambassador to Australia says a working group will travel to Brisbane as the search for a man who threw hot coffee on a baby in 2024 continues. Nine-month-old Luka was with his family at Hanlon Park in Stones Corner when it was alleged a 33-year-old man approached them and threw a thermos of hot coffee over the infant. title: Travel agents warn of 'chaos' as UK institutes new passport rules | ABC NEWS
description: The British government has implemented new requirements for dual citizens entering the UK.  Soon UK-Australian dual citizens will need to enter the UK using their British passport.  Belle Goldie works in the travel industry and explains how her customers have been affected by the new passport rules for dual citizens travelling to the UK. She warns that scammers are taking advantage of the changes and targeting people who want to fast track their passports. title: US authorities say Washington DC air crash was "100% preventable" | ABC NEWS
description: The National Transport Safety Bureau says a mid-air collision between a passenger plane and Army helicopter in Washington D.C. was 'completely preventable'.  The air crash investigators says Army helicopters were allowed to fly too close to passenger jets and found failings in Army safety culture contributed to the crash.
